title: 114_s254
content: The Small Business Health Relief Act of 2015 aims to make coverage affordable for small businesses by protecting American jobs and wages, increasing flexibility, choices for Americans, and ensuring affordable coverage. It also focuses on increasing consumer control by repealing restrictions on over-the-counter medicines and annual caps. Additionally, it allows individuals to keep the coverage they like. SEC. 101. Protecting American jobs and wages under the Small Business Health Relief Act of 2015. The Small Business Health Relief Act of 2015 repeals the Shared Responsibility Payment for Employers regarding health coverage by amending the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. This includes striking section 4980H and making conforming amendments to related sections of the Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act. Section 1411 of the Small Business Health Relief Act of 2015 is amended to establish procedures for appeals and redeterminations by the Secretary and other Federal officers. This includes hearing appeals and making decisions on determinations, as well as periodic redeterminations of eligibility. Additionally, subsection (i) is struck from Section 1411 and Section 1412(a)(2) is amended to include notification requirements to the Exchange and the Secretary of the Treasury. The amendments made by this subsection apply to months after December 31, 2013. Subpart D of part III of subchapter A of chapter 61 of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended by striking section 6056. Conforming amendments are made to sections 6724(d)(1)(B) and 6724(d)(2) of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. The amendments made by this subsection shall apply to periods beginning after December 31, 2013. Section 6724(d)(2) of the Internal Revenue Code is amended by removing subparagraph (HH) and making changes to subparagraphs (FF) and (GG). SEC. 102 repeals a section of the Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act. SEC. 103 aims to increase choices for Americans. SEC. 102 amends the Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act to allow high deductible health plans with health savings accounts to meet coverage requirements. Conforming amendments are also made. The Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act is amended to remove certain provisions related to coverage requirements and catastrophic coverage. The Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act is amended to repeal certain provisions related to protecting patients from higher premiums and ensuring affordable coverage. Additionally, restrictions on over-the-counter medicines are also repealed to increase consumer control. SEC. 201 repeals restrictions on over-the-counter medicines for various health savings accounts and arrangements, effective for taxable years beginning after December 31, 2014. SEC. 202 repeals the annual cap on health savings accounts, effective for taxable years beginning after December 31, 2014. It also allows individuals to keep their current coverage if they like it. The Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act is amended to protect employers and consumers with grandfathered coverage in group health plans or health insurance. This applies to plans in which individuals are enrolled after March 23, 2010, but before a year after the enactment date. The Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act protects grandfathered health plans from losing their status due to modifications in cost-sharing levels, employer contributions, or covered benefits. The Secretary will issue regulations to clarify this provision. The amendments made by this section shall take effect as if included in the enactment of the Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act. Any previously promulgated regulations relating to section 1251(a)(2) of such Act shall have no force or effect.
